Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CS in Parallel: Scaling an Incremental Modular Approach to Injecting Parallel Computing Throughout CS Curricula

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The shift to parallel computing, including multi-core processors, cloud computing, and heterogeneous systems, has induced a workforce development crisis for computer science (CS) education. This project addresses how crowded CS curricula, traditionally structured around sequential (non-parallel) computing, can be changed to effectively incorporate the rapidly-evolving body of parallelism knowledge.

Saint Olaf College, Calvin College and Macalester College are demonstrating how colleges and universities can insert short (one- to three-day) teaching modules on parallel computing into their courses through self-contained units that present conceptual principles and reinforce them by hands-on experience and follow-up exercises. New modules that incorporate emerging curricular recommendations, relevant applications to other fields, and parallel design patterns are under development. Parallelism is infused incrementally throughout the CS curriculum. Having developed this modular strategy in a predecessor CCLI Type I grant, this project demonstrates the scalability of this approach to other universities and colleges by targeting two geographical regions with workshops and follow-up adopter support.

Other project activities reward participants for creating new modules, promote the national dissemination of this modular approach through conference workshops and presentations, and expand existing synergistic partnerships between CSinParallel.org and related efforts in industry, academia, and professional organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to improve the curriculum of computer science programs at various types of undergraduate institutions by enabling computer science educators to easily add parallel and distributed computing computing to all levels of the computer science (CS) curriculum. Inspired by the fact that multicore processors are the only available technology today and that distributed computation via networked clusters of computers is increasingly commonplace, we developed and disseminated a series of teaching modules that could be introduced in any CS course and take only a short amount of class time. This makes it possible to change an institutions' curriculum in incremental ways to meet the newest guidelines for computer science curricula, published by our professional computing societies. These guidelines now contain many new recommendations for including parallel and distributed computing, and our timely project enables instructors to fulfill those guidelines. The materials are freely availble on http://csinparallel.org.

We sought to demonstrate that groups of CS educators could work together to affect the changes needed at their institutions by attending our workshops and forming a comunity commited to improving CS education to meet the current state of our computing hardware. Many educators attended our workshops and used our curricular materials, thereby teaching the next generation of computer scientists how to make proper use of muticore and distributed computing technology to improve computational applications in all types of areas. The knowledge these students obtained will have lasting effects on their contributions to society.
